questions.question_text: Which of the following features allows for the separation of authentication, authorization, and accounting?

discussion.content:
C is correct, per Schmidt
"Two other technologies used with authentication are RADIUS and TACACS. The Remote Authentication Dial-in User Service (RADIUS) protocol is used to centralize authentication,
authorization, and accounting (AAA). A RADIUS server can provide a way to authenticate wired and wireless users as well as devices before they are allowed to communicate on the network. Terminal Access Controller Access Control System (TACACS) also supports
AAA, and it also makes it possible to separate the pieces of AAA so you don’t have to do all three on the same server. You could do authentication on a different server but still support authorization and accounting on a TACACS server, for example."

questions.question_text:
When opening a browser, a user receives pop-ups and is redirected to a certain website. A technician discovers a newer form of malware has infected the machine via an email attachment. The technician updates the anti-malware software and is able to clean the machine.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

choices.B: Create a System Restore point of the newly cleaned machine.
choices.A: Redeploy the machine back into the production environment.
choices.D: Update any other anti-malware software and patch the operating system.
choices.C: Explain proper email scanning techniques to the user.

comments.content: but isn't D step 5, they are talking about updating and patching the operating system... what you guys think of option D

No lad, from the question we know the tech has completed the remediation (step 4). Next should be step 5 or schedule scans/updates, but is not listed. So onto step 6 which is enable sys restore and create a restore point (answer B). Step 7 is educating end user (answer C), but step 6 comes first naturally. B is correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following security permissions takes precedence over the other?

discussion.content:
The hierarchy of precedence for the permissions can be summarized as follows, with the higher precedence permissions listed at the top of the list:

Explicit Deny
Explicit Allow
Inherited Deny
Inherited Allow
Also true: File permissions override folder permissions, unless the Full Control permission has been granted to the folder.

comments.content:
Thanks for this!
So the question/answers can be read:
“Which is true?”
A) [explicit] over [implicit] (correct)
B) [implicit] over [implicit]
C) [implicit] over [explicit]
D) [explicit] over [explicit]

questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a SOHO wireless network for a healthcare office that does not have a server. The user requires the highest level of wireless security and various levels of desktop authentication to access cloud resources.
Which of the following protocols and authentication methods should the technician implement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
It asks for highest level of WIRELESS SECURITY and VARIOUS LEVELS of desktop authentication. 

Highest Level: WPA2
Various Levels: MFA

WEP stands for Wired Equivalent Privacy, and WPA stands for Wireless Protected Access. WPA2 is the second version of the WPA standard. ... WPA2 is the most secure of the three. If your wireless card and router support WPA2, that is what you should use when setting up your wireless network.
Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) is a security protocol, specified in the IEEE Wireless Fidelity (Wi-Fi) standard, 802.11b. That standard is designed to provide a wireless local area network (WLAN) with a level of security and privacy comparable to what is usually expected of a wired LAN.

comments.content: RADIUS AND TACACS are for servers, not for a SOHO environment i believe wpa2 and multifactor are the best for that particular case
How about TACACS? It just need router as well
Radius requires an authentication server. The question states that the office doesn't have a server.

questions.question_text:
A technician needs to troubleshoot a user's computer while the user is connected to the system. The technician must also connect to the user's system using remote access tools built in to Windows.
Which of the following is the BEST option to troubleshoot the user's computer?

discussion.content: Only possible answer would be MSRA, because its Remote Assistance and itd Microsoft tool embedded in system. RDP disconnect user, while remote assistance offers customer/user to see what are you doing on his screen (you and he have control over the mouse pointer) , and when u close MSRA he can continue his work without signing out/getting disconnected and so on..
RDP will disconnec the user and send them to the sign in screen, I believe that screen mirroring is the answer
